claims.claim_text: A stack is a data structure that follows the principle of Last In, First Out (LIFO). It stores data items and uses push and pop operations to add or remove them. This means the last item added is the first one to be removed.
claims.top_evidence:
NOTES:
Stack A stack is a linear data structure which is used to store data items and follows the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO). First In - Last Out (FILO): It is a considered list in which addition of new data items and deletion of existing data items is done from one end known as the top of the stack. The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: A Last In - First Out (LIFO) data structure is a way to organize information, similar to a stack of trays. When you add an item (push), it goes on top, and when you remove an item (pop), it's the last one added that comes off first. This principle helps in managing tasks or data where the order of removal follows the order of addition.

The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: "First In - Last Out (FILO) refers to a method in which the last item added to a stack is the first one to be removed. This principle, used in various data structures, ensures that the order of entry determines the order of exit."

claims.claim_text: The "Top of the Stack" refers to the last item added in a stack, which is the first one to be removed. This position holds the most recently pushed data item in a linear data structure that follows the Last In - First Out (LIFO) principle.

claims.claim_text: Inserting an element into a stack is known as pushing. This operation adds a new item to the top of the stack, following the Last In - First Out (LIFO) principle. The opposite of insertion, or removing an element from the top of the stack, is called popping.

The insertion and deletion operations in stack are known as push and pop operations.

claims.claim_text: Deletion from a stack refers to removing the last item added (top element) using an operation called 'pop'. This is part of how stacks function, following the principle of Last In - First Out (LIFO).
